bestBHT.bht: Believers have a common cause, urging them to stand together for their faith. The opposition they face can be intense, as seen in the person who greatly withstood their words, possibly in the events at Ephesus. Timothy, therefore, must be on his guard and protect himself from this harmful influence. The individual vigorously opposed the believers' teachings, resorting to blasphemy and personal attacks. It was necessary for Timothy to avoid their company and remain vigilant against the damage they could cause.

Philip Schaff: 2 Timothy 4:15. He greatly withstood our words. The words point to some discussion ending (if we assume identity with 1 Timothy 1:20) in St. Paul’s delivering him to Satan.
Archibald T. Robertson: Be thou ware also (κα συ φυλασσου). Present middle (direct) imperative of φυλασσω, 'from whom keep thyself away.'
Withstood (αντεστη). Second aorist active indicative of ανθιστημ, 'stood against my words.' See 2 Timothy 3:8; Galatians 2:11.
John Gill: For he was such a malicious, ill-natured, and troublesome person, as well as a blasphemer, an heretic, and had been delivered up to Satan.
It was very advisable to shun his company, and have no conversation with him, and be upon the guard against him, that he might have no opportunity of doing hurt.
He opposed himself to, and resisted with all his might, and endeavored to confute and overthrow; and wherein he was deficient in argument, he made up with railing and blasphemy.
